Use: Stories, episodes of TV series, etc.

Pronunciation: ほん hon, ぽん pon, ぼん bon
Use: frequently used word Long, thin objects: rivers, roads, train tracks, ties, pencils, bottles, guitars; also, metaphorically, telephone calls, train or bus routes, movies (see also: tsūwa), points or bounds in sports events. Although the kanji also means "book", the counter for books is satsu.
Frequently used word Occurrences, number of times (see also: do)

Pronunciation: ど do, also たび tabi
Use: Occurrences, number of times, degrees of temperature or angle (see also: kai).
Copies of a magazine or newspaper, or other packets of papers
People, used in the words 一人 and 二人)
Frequently used word Thin, flat objects: sheets of paper, photographs, plates, articles of clothing (see also: chaku)
Cars, bicycles, machines, mechanical devices, household appliances
General-purpose counter, used as part of the indigenous Japanese numbers ("one thing"), ("two things")
frequently used word Implies that the item is small and/or round. The kanji is also used for military units.

Pronunciation: かい kai, がい gai
ひき hiki, ぴき piki, びき biki
Use: Small animals, insects, fish, reptiles, amphibians, oni (demons/ogres)

Pronunciation: はい hai, ぱい pai, ばい bai
Use: Cups and glasses of drink, spoonsful; cuttlefish, octopuses, crabs, squid, abalone, boats (slang)

Pronunciation: はく haku, ぱく paku

Use: Tatami mats. The kanji is also read tatami and is the same one used for the mats. The room size of a washitsu in Japan is given as a number of mats, for example 4½ jō
frequently used word Implies that the item is small and/or round.

Month-long periods (see also: gatsu). The kanji is normally abbreviated using a small katakana ヶ in modern Japanese. Alternatively 個, hiragana か, small katakana ヵ and full-size katakana カ & ケ can also be seen, although only か is similarly frequent.
Points, dots, pieces of a set
Images, statues, person's remains, dolls, androids, humanoid robots
Large animals, cattle, elephants, whales, dolphins, butterflies (the kanji means "head")
Mirrors, boards for board games (chess, igo, shogi), stages of computer games, walls of a room, tennis courts
Board game matches (chess, igo, shogi, mahjong); radio stations, television stations

Pronunciation: ひん hin, ぴん pin
Use: Parts of a meal, courses (see also: shina)
Parts of a meal, courses (see also: hin)
Pairs of footwear, pairs of socks, stockings, tabi
Articles of law, thin objects, rays or streams of light, streaks of smoke or lightning
Sets of things, such as documents or furniture
Used as part of the indigenous Japanese numbers

Pronunciation: しゅるい shurui or しゅ shu
しゅるい shurui or しゅ shu

Use: Groups, a pair of people (twins, a husband and a wife, dancers, etc.)

Pronunciation: まき maki or かん kan
Use: Rolls, scrolls, kan for volumes of book

Pronunciation: はつ hatsu, ぱつ patsu
Use: Gunshots, bullets, aerial fireworks; orgasms, sex acts

Pronunciation: ふく fuku, ぷく puku
Use: Bowls of matcha (powdered green tea); packets or doses of powdered medicine; puffs (of, e.g., a cigarette); rests or breaks

Pronunciation: ふく fuku, ぷく puku
ひょう hyō, ぴょう pyō
ごん gon, also こと koto

Use: Graves, wreaths, CPUs, reactors, elevators, dams
Children. As in "father of two (children)", etc.

Pronunciation: わ wa, ば ba, ぱ pa
けん ken, げん gen

Use: small container (e.g. rice cup, sake cup)
Suits of armour, sets of furniture
Frames, panels. 齣 is virtually unused nowadays.
Sequences of letters or drawings that you write or draw without removing your pen off the paper. Not to be confused with "hitsu" below.

Pronunciation: ひつ hitsu, ぴつ pitsu
Use: pices of land and number of people
Small fish and shrimps (used in the fish trade; most people say hiki instead)
Boxes made of folded paper (compare to hako above, which refers to boxes in general)
Bows during worship at a shrine
Ships, half of a pair (e.g., half of a folding screen), item carried in a bundle (fish, birds, arrows etc.)
bundles (of banknotes), bunches (of flowers, vegetables), sheaves
Food portions (without exceptions, unlike nin above)
Tools, scissors, saws, trousers, pistols, cakes of tofu, town blocks, servings at a restaurant
